simulated_ratings.title: Vanilla Sky (2001)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A romantic, reality-bending fever dream that scratches my mind-bender itch.

simulated_ratings.title: Cloud Atlas (2012)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A sweeping, soulful tangle of lives and ideas that I admire more than I love.

simulated_ratings.title: Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind (2004)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Painfully beautiful and imaginative

simulated_ratings.title: Her (2013)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A tender, futuristic love story that feels warmly human and quietly devastating.

simulated_ratings.title: Street Fight (2005)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A tense, clear-eyed campaign portrait that kept me engaged and frustrated in equal measure.

simulated_ratings.title: Blue Is the Warmest Color (La vie d'Adèle) (2013)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Raw, intimate, and absorbing

simulated_ratings.title: Little Women (2019)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Warm, earnest, and charming, even if its comforts feel familiar.

simulated_ratings.title: Harvie Krumpet (2003)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Quirky, bittersweet, and ultimately uplifting in its own odd way.

simulated_ratings.title: Curious Case of Benjamin Button, The (2008)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A lush, melancholy romance with a gentle, time-bending pull.

simulated_ratings.title: Eyes Wide Shut (1999)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Hypnotic and unsettling

simulated_ratings.title: In the Bleak Midwinter (1995)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sweetly scrappy and good-natured, if a bit slight for me.

simulated_ratings.title: Black Swan (2010)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Visceral and claustrophobic

simulated_ratings.title: Solaris (2002)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Quiet, mournful sci-fi that trades spectacle for mood, which I appreciated.

simulated_ratings.title: Amelie (Fabuleux destin d'Amélie Poulain, Le) (2001)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Whimsical, tender, and generous

simulated_ratings.title: Blue Valentine (2010)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Intimate and bruising, with honesty that stings.

simulated_ratings.title: Pervert's Guide to Ideology, The (2012)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Provocative and brainy, intriguing more than it moves me.

simulated_ratings.title: Inception (2010)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A sleek, clever puzzle with heart enough to matter.

simulated_ratings.title: Young Poisoner's Handbook, The (1995)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Darkly funny and unsettling in a way I enjoyed.

simulated_ratings.title: Gravity (2013)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A tense, immersive survival rush that left me breathless.

simulated_ratings.title: Er ist wieder da (2015)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A sharp idea with bold satire that hits and misses for me.

simulated_ratings.title: Priest (1994)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sincere and thoughtful, if a little blunt in its messaging.

simulated_ratings.title: Playing by Heart (1998)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Patchwork romance with enough honest moments to win me over.

simulated_ratings.title: Interstellar (2014)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Grand and emotional, big ideas anchored by real feeling.

simulated_ratings.title: Mr. Nobody (2009)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A wistful, kaleidoscopic life maze that I loved getting lost in.

simulated_ratings.title: Other Sister, The (1999)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sweet intentions, but the sentimentality felt heavy-handed to me.

simulated_ratings.title: Exit Through the Gift Shop (2010)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Playful, sly, and energizing

recommended_movies: The Wrestling Women vs. the Aztec Mummy (1964)

simulated_ratings.title: Go Fish (1994)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Scrappy, candid and endearingly awkward, its sincerity wins me over.

simulated_ratings.title: Happiness (1998)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Bracingly bleak and darkly funny, I admired its nerve more than I loved the experience.

simulated_ratings.title: eXistenZ (1999)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A lo-fi, squishy mind-game that tickles my reality-bender itch.

simulated_ratings.title: The Wrestling Women vs. the Aztec Mummy (1964)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Campy pulp with occasional goofy charm, but mostly a slog for me.

simulated_ratings.title: Dirty Grandpa (2016)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Crass and exhausting far more than it’s funny, not my brand of comedy.

simulated_ratings.title: Human Nature (2001)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Quirky, clever and uneven, amusing ideas that don’t quite move me.

simulated_ratings.title: Girl in the Café, The (2005)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Tender, gentle and quietly political in a way I found appealing.

simulated_ratings.title: Chicago (2002)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Slick and snappy, entertaining but emotionally thin for me.

simulated_ratings.title: Les Pépites (2016)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Modest and heartfelt, engaging but not revelatory.

simulated_ratings.title: Cecil B. DeMented (2000)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A rowdy anarchic movie love letter that is messy but fun in its chaos.

simulated_ratings.title: Thoroughbreds (2018)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Icy, mordant and precise, its wicked composure really worked for me.

simulated_ratings.title: Into the Woods (1991)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Clever and playful, though the stagey delivery kept me at a bit of a distance.

simulated_ratings.title: Cell, The (2000)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Visually arresting and nightmarish, even if the story feels thin.

simulated_ratings.title: Joe's Apartment (1996)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Goofy and gross-out whimsical, which wore out its welcome for me.

simulated_ratings.title: Steve Jobs: The Lost Interview (2012)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Lean, candid and stimulating, catnip for the tech-curious.

simulated_ratings.title: Prime Time (2021)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Taut and intimate, with a simmering desperation I appreciated.

simulated_ratings.title: Sea Wife (1957)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A dated survival melodrama with sparks of tension but limited impact on me.

simulated_ratings.title: Fresh (2022)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A sharp, queasy riff on modern dating that kept me hooked.

simulated_ratings.title: Hardware Wars (1978)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Cute and scrappy parody that is more charming than actually funny for me.

simulated_ratings.title: Finding His Voice (1929)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Historically neat and lightly amusing, more curiosity than keeper.

simulated_ratings.title: Titanic (1953)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Classically mounted and affecting enough, though a bit restrained for the grand romance I crave.

simulated_ratings.title: It Ain't Over (2023)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A warm, affectionate portrait that is easy to enjoy even as a non-fan.

simulated_ratings.title: Last Summer in the Hamptons (1995)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Talky, theatrical family fireworks that I found engaging if uneven.

simulated_ratings.title: May Fools (Milou en mai) (1990)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Gentle and wry, fond of its eccentricities in a way that charmed me.

simulated_ratings.title: Let Me In (2010)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Moody, tender and haunting, a remake that still lands emotionally.

simulated_ratings.feeling: Creepy premise and some chills, even if it feels familiar.

simulated_ratings.title: Bride & Prejudice (2004)

simulated_ratings.feeling: Sharp and often funny, but the crassness wears thin for me.

simulated_ratings.title: Thirty-Two Short Films About Glenn Gould (1993)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Inventive, contemplative portraits that resonated with me.

simulated_ratings.title: Jakob the Liar (1999)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sincere and well-meaning, but the sentimentality dulled its impact for me.

simulated_ratings.title: Wedding Crashers (2005)

simulated_ratings.title: Star Wars: The Last Jedi (2017)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Spectacle with enough heart and ideas to keep me engaged.

simulated_ratings.title: Belladonna of Sadness (1973)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Visually hypnotic and haunting, though the trauma is hard to sit with.

simulated_ratings.title: Dave Chappelle: For What it's Worth (2004)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Smart, loose, and frequently hilarious, even when it needles.
